column4: supposedly Samsung is open sourcing drivers for the Galaxy S II ... but I haven't looked to see if they are out there, yet
Some of the hardware in the phones call stacks use a lot of proprietary tech I think, so they can't open them.
they _said_ they were ... issue as you mention might delay or prevent that ... need to find out if it ever happens
if Samsung does want to go open and gain a market edge that way, they are big enough to force chip makers and such to accept open
Android's about as open as it gets though - I develop on the platform, and also OSX -  there's a big difference :-)
I need to get into doing Android ... but my love for OS building means I want ot build the whole thing from source and load my own image on to my Galaxy S II
Like most corps though, they do whatever makes the most money - if there's no advantage to opening up some other parts of a product, they don't do it
wow ... are they all unlocked or rooted?
No, just normal phones - no sim cards, unlocked - they only need wireless connections at the  next event.
you got that wifi adhoc walkit-talkie app on them?
They're going to be running an app I'm working on - nothing else really.
what does your app do?  gonna open source it?
No, it's specifically for a corporate event - it has no purpose outside of that. Like most of my stuff, it's all owned by the client after i hand it over.
I see ... work for hire stuff
but you could build an open source app if you wanted to

Yep. I did a job for the Google stand at the Mobile World Conference inBarcelona a few months back. A Claw arcade machine controlled by an Android tablet (using tilt and touch). Even the Google CEO had a go - heh
You can see it on Youtube still I think. Had little Android toys in it for people to win. There were queues on it (plus 2 other clone machines) all day every day at the conference :-)
